clinical_study.brief_title: Patient's Perception in Symptoms Related to Morning Activity Based on Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Observational, Multi-center, Non-interventional Study to Assess Patients Perception in SYmptoms Related to Morning Activity Based on Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to assess the perception of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients in symptoms related to morning activities. Also the researchers investigated how to describe the impact of symptoms on sleep quality and how to use the medication in Korea COPD treatments.

primary_outcome.measure: To assess the perception of COPD Patients in symptoms related to morning activities
primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and last visit (after 2~3 months)

secondary_outcome.measure: To assess the patient's perception of the variability of symptoms
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and last visit (after 2~3 months)

secondary_outcome.measure: To describe how patients use their COPD treatments
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and last visit (after 2~3 months)

study_pop.textblock: The inclusion/exclusion criteria are designed to select subjects suffering from severe COPD (according to spirometric classification, GOLD stage III and IV) and in a stable state

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- COPD outpatients over 45 years old
- Lung function: post-FEV1 < 50%
- Current or ex-smoker > 10 packs per year
- Patients who were not on medication of ISC/FC at least 2 weeks
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ongoing exacerbation of COPD or within the previous 3 months
- History of asthma or allergic rhinitis
- Lung cancer or any other significant respiratory disease such as bronchiectasis, lung fibrosis, interstitial lung disease, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis
- Current participation in an interventional clinical trial
